flags.title: User-Contributed Project
flags.text: This project guide is not managed by MAKE staff.

guide.introduction: For too long I've been standing in the stream of chips flying off my milling machine. This small shield sticks to my milling vise magnetically, and takes less than an hour to make. It does a good job of helping keep chips contained, especially when using cutting fluid or fly cutters. I've also found it to be useful on my drill press.
guide.introduction_rendered:
For too long I've been standing in the stream of chips flying off my milling machine. This small shield sticks to my milling vise magnetically, and takes less than an hour to make. It does a good job of helping keep chips contained, especially when using cutting fluid or fly cutters. I've also found it to be useful on my drill press.

Relevant parts
  • Aluminum bar
  • Neodymium magnet
  • 6-32 Set Screw
  • 1/4" Plexiglass
Tools
  • 6-32 Tap
  • Hack saw
  • Milling machine

parts.notes: This should be no smaller than 5/8" x 1/2" x 4"

lines.text: Take the rough bar, and trim it to 4" x 5/8" x 1/2".
lines.text_raw: Take the rough bar, and trim it to 4" x 5/8" x 1/2".

lines.text: Dimensions aren't very critical in this project; if you have a 5/8" x 1/2" bar, just take a very light cut off each side to make it look nice.
lines.text_raw: Dimensions aren't very critical in this project; if you have a 5/8" x 1/2" bar, just take a very light cut off each side to make it look nice.

lines.text: Mill a 0.25" wide groove 0.25" deep. It should be in 0.10" from one edge.
lines.text_raw: Mill a 0.25" wide groove 0.25" deep. It should be in 0.10" from one edge.

lines.text: I'm using one of these chip shields in the second photo. Notice the pile of chips behind it and lack of chips in front.
lines.text_raw: I'm using one of these chip shields in the second photo. Notice the pile of chips behind it and lack of chips in front.

lines.text: Cutting the groove in the last step created a thin side and a thick side. These holes will be drilled through the thick side.
lines.text_raw: Cutting the groove in the last step created a thin side and a thick side. These holes will be drilled through the thick side.

lines.text: Spot, drill, and tap three holes 0.125" from the top, at 1", 2", and 3" in from one end.
lines.text_raw: Spot, drill, and tap three holes 0.125" from the top, at 1", 2", and 3" in from one end.

lines.text: Drill two holes on the bottom with a drill bit the same diameter as the magnets. Don't drill all the way through, just deep enough for the magnets to sit flush.
lines.text_raw: Drill two holes on the bottom with a drill bit the same diameter as the magnets. Don't drill all the way through, just deep enough for the magnets to sit flush.

lines.text: Glue in the magnets with J-B Weld or another suitable glue. Make sure they are perfectly flush with the bottom of the part.
lines.text_raw: Glue in the magnets with J-B Weld or another suitable glue. Make sure they are perfectly flush with the bottom of the part.

lines.text: Cut a piece of 0.25" thick plexiglass. Make it whatever dimensions best fit your machines. 4" x 3" is a convenient size for me.
lines.text_raw: Cut a piece of 0.25" thick plexiglass. Make it whatever dimensions best fit your machines. 4" x 3" is a convenient size for me.

lines.text: Slide it into the slot, and insert three 6-32 setscrews into the holes you drilled and tapped. Stick it to your machine and enjoy!
lines.text_raw: Slide it into the slot, and insert three 6-32 setscrews into the holes you drilled and tapped. Stick it to your machine and enjoy!

lines.text: This cannot replace safety glasses, nor is it meant to. It just helps reduce the amount of swarf flying at you.
lines.text_raw: This cannot replace safety glasses, nor is it meant to. It just helps reduce the amount of swarf flying at you.

guide.summary: In under an hour, build a small shield to shelter you from flying chips.
guide.title: Magnetic Chip Shield
